item.title: By: tillerofthesoil
item.dc:creator: tillerofthesoil
item.description:
Are there no meditative breathing practices native to Jews?:
“What is [the vowel] חוֹלֶם [ḥolem]? It is the נְשָׁמָה [neshama] soul – its name is חוֹלֶם [ḥolem]. If you תִּשְׁמַע [tishema] listen, your body will be תַּחְלִים [taḥlim] reinvigorated, in the future of its builder [cf. BT Berakhot 60b: My God, the נְשָׁמָה [neshama] soul, that you placed within me is pure… You will take it from me and restore it to me in the time to come]. But if you rebel against it, there will be חוֹלֶה [ḥoleh] illness, on your head, and חוֹלִים [ḥolim] illnesses, on its head” (Bahir 40).
נְשָׁמָה (neshama) soul, shares a root with נְשִׁימָה (neshimah) breath, and thus our Bahir passage can be interpreted to mean: תִּשְׁמַע (tishema) listen, to your נְשִׁימָה (neshimah) breath.
